title: As Always, ADCS ruin Everything
body:
Well, as the title implies, we get to see the nerf of another item soon because ADCs always have to abuse items from other classes.

Relic shield is the current go to for ADCs because it gives them a convenient shield and tankiness as well as sustain for their support and a little extra gold for them at the small cost of a teeny bit of a damage early game that is heavily negated by the sustain and utility of the shield. 

ADCs can't just use the items their own class provides and always have to ruin it for others such as duskblade, Steraks, and now Relic shield. Sorry tank supports, it was meant for you but the when you have a class like ADC that has design flaws like it does, we all have to pay our dues.

~~That seems oddly sarcastic to me, I'm being genuine in discussing this with you and I would appreciate if you did the same.~~

This was rude of me, I see that you were being serious. My apologies for misreading the situation.

Unfortunately, Riot has a contradictory stance on item diversity. They want everything to be available to everyone (Build diversity). But they only a small range of items to be good on each champion (Item balance). Until they get over this mental hurtle, such a system isn't likely to even be considered.
That said, there *is* precedent in the jungling items.

As for implementation, it would be fairly straight forward. Most items would be generic to all shops with group specific specializations To reduce workload).

>Step 1: identify the categories you want to separate.
Examples include (based on old stated itemization philosophies)...
 - Mage: Lots of mana and AP. Uniques include Deathcap and Tear.
 - Marksman: Crit and MS. Uniques include the shard line.
 - Fighter: health and damage. Uniques include Steraks and Hydra.
 - Tank: Health, resists, and general defensive steroids. Uniques Omen, Adaptive, and Warmogs.
 - Assassin: Windowed power and mobility. Uniques include Duskblade, Duskmantle, and Luden's.
 - Support: "all the cheap sh\*t." Like current itemization, will specialize in powerful effects, cost efficiency, and sustain. Uniques include... Well.... This group will probably require the most work since it also traditionally has the most problems.

Step 2: Identify problem items that should be separated. (See above examples.)


>Step 3: Identify Edge cases.
Since most items are generic, edge cases should still get by with minimal work. Only four that come immediately to mind...
- Kayne - Dual form thing would be tricky. You try to give him some type of stat conversion ans a band-aid. But I'm not really qualified to evaluate a champion I've never even touched to know what he needs.
- Quinn - The separation would hurt her. But she should still be able to function in Assassin or Marksman trees.
- Nidalee - Like all stance changers (except Gnar), she always has a clearly optimal form. So her decision is tied more to the meta than anything in-game.
- Graves - We officially stop trying to convince ourselves this guy isn't a ranged fighter.

Step 4: Balance champions/items accordingly.

--------------------

This process would probably have to be a pre-season thing given the level of back-end work that would be involved. Though game-play impact would likely be relatively small. Which brings us to another reason against Riot implementation: Feedback.
Reducing build diversity (even if it's tenuous) is likely to create a lot of back-lash while adding knowledge burdens to the new player experience. And would have a very small end gain. So there's little PR incentive.

As for the runes thing; yes is was a joke. But we already know Riot likes making these pre-game bonuses. It would be possible to shift the passive stat buffs in runes to this system, since you can generally get a better idea of what a person is after. As opposed to the rune trees which are meant to cover a relatively wide net of play styles. 

Example:
- Marksman will want AD and AS.
- Mages will want AP and Mana.
- Fighters will want resists to balance out their shop being health heavy.
- Tanks will want supplemental damage to cover their early-game laning/jungling; the shop will cover all their defensive needs. Flat bonus damage + scaling health bonus perhaps.
- Assassins want more damage. Could give adaptive AD/AP.
- Supports want gold gen and sustain. Which (in theory) should be able too safely move to here since anyone taking this grouping is agreeing to knee-cap that stats.

> Unfortunately, Riot has a contradictory stance on item diversity. They want everything to be available to everyone (Build diversity). But they only a small range of items to be good on each champion (Item balance). Until they get over this mental hurtle, such a system isn't likely to even be considered.

I agree, this is definitely the main part of the problem. They can't seem to get past the idea that they want to promote diversity. I think that they are too gun-shy with limiting access to items that are being abused. And their efforts to balance those items for both their intended users and for the abuse cases often hurts the intended users.

> That said, there is precedent in the jungling items.

> As for implementation, it would be fairly straight forward. Most items would be generic to all shops with group specific specializations To reduce workload).

>    Step 1: identify the categories you want to separate.
>    Examples include (based on old stated itemization philosophies)...
>
>        Mage: Lots of mana and AP. Uniques include Deathcap and Tear.
>        Marksman: Crit and MS. Uniques include the shard line.
>        Fighter: health and damage. Uniques include Steraks and Hydra.
>        Tank: Health, resists, and general defensive steroids. Uniques Omen, Adaptive, and Warmogs.
>        Assassin: Windowed power and mobility. Uniques include Duskblade, Duskmantle, and Luden's.
>        Support: "all the cheap sh*t." Like current itemization, will specialize in powerful effects, cost efficiency, and sustain. Uniques include... Well.... This group will probably require the most work since it also traditionally has the most problems.

I like the direction of this, but I'm not sure I agree with how many items you are locking out. In particular, I think that items such as Randuin's Omen and Adaptive Helm offer extremely important counters to otherwise very obnoxious or powerful builds/champions.

As such I would either want these 'counter items' to be available to everyone or want certain classes of champions to have access to items from multiple categories, for example fighters or juggernauts should be given access to at least some of the tank items as well.

>Step 2: Identify problem items that should be separated. (See above examples.)

Indeed, also see above response.

>    Step 3: Identify Edge cases.
>    Since most items are generic, edge cases should still get by with minimal work. Only four that come immediately to mind...
>
>        Kayne - Dual form thing would be tricky. You try to give him some type of stat conversion ans a band-aid. But I'm not really qualified to evaluate a champion I've never even touched to know what he needs.
>        Quinn - The separation would hurt her. But she should still be able to function in Assassin or Marksman trees.
>        Nidalee - Like all stance changers (except Gnar), she always has a clearly optimal form. So her decision is tied more to the meta than anything in-game.
>        Graves - We officially stop trying to convince ourselves this guy isn't a ranged fighter.

Yeah, I imagine that it would work best if the system were based off of a player choice of some kind. Players who pick a champion could have their pick between the various classes to gain access to those class specific items, and then in-game champions who are hybrid or who switch would either be given access to a second class's items or they would be given a choice to switch (like in Kayne's case) if they are forced to change or if they want to change.

Maybe people could even be given the freedom to build items outside of their chosen class, but until they select a different class, they don't get the full benefits of those items.

> Step 4: Balance champions/items accordingly.

> This process would probably have to be a pre-season thing given the level of back-end work that would be involved. Though game-play impact would likely be relatively small. Which brings us to another reason against Riot implementation: Feedback.
Reducing build diversity (even if it's tenuous) is likely to create a lot of back-lash while adding knowledge burdens to the new player experience. And would have a very small end gain. So there's little PR incentive.

I personally think that by limiting choices by category or class, and by giving newer players recommendations, we could actually see the new player experience improved, and people would be less likely to do things like buy Rabadon's Deathcap or Randuin's Omen while playing something like Ashe.

That said, I do understand that with any heavy-handed change, it is likely to incur backlash. And I understand that Riot might not want to deal with that when there are easier changes they can make that might not anger as many people.

> As for the runes thing; yes is was a joke. But we already know Riot likes making these pre-game bonuses. It would be possible to shift the passive stat buffs in runes to this system, since you can generally get a better idea of what a person is after. As opposed to the rune trees which are meant to cover a relatively wide net of play styles.

> Example:
> - Marksman will want AD and AS.
> - Mages will want AP and Mana.
> - Fighters will want resists to balance out their shop being health heavy.
> - Tanks will want supplemental damage to cover their early-game laning/jungling; the shop will cover all their defensive needs. Flat bonus damage + scaling health bonus perhaps.
> - Assassins want more damage. Could give adaptive AD/AP.
> - Supports want gold gen and sustain. Which (in theory) should be able too safely move to here since anyone taking this grouping is agreeing to knee-cap that stats.

Okay I see what you mean now. Sorry for not taking it as a joke before, I was a bit on edge the other day from dealing with stupid stuff elsewhere.

This actually would make a lot of sense and I see why it could work well. I do really like the idea of moving the passive bonuses to the class system because it reduces the burden on players of trying to pick rune trees in the right order to get the stats they want, and it makes runes and class selection much easier for Riot to balance because it would be separate them from one another and put stat selection in a much more comprehensive place.

> I like the direction of this, but I'm not sure I agree with how many items you are locking out. In particular, I think that items such as Randuin's Omen and Adaptive Helm offer extremely important counters to otherwise very obnoxious or powerful builds/champions.

I agree they are powerful counters. I listed them specifically because of *why* they are counters. They contain unmitigateable resists. Specificly, 20% reduced crit damage and 20% reduced repeat magic damage. Personal philosophy, those type of defenses should be restricted *from* squishies. One perk of this concept is the ability to mitigate arms races. Items get resists, then resist shred, items get health, we get BotRK, Riot gives us omen, then gives us Dominick's.
Under this example, Fighters get a lot of health which works against AP and AD equally (in theory). Everyone has access to resist items. Tanks have access to additional defense steroids. I imagine a scenario where the tank specialized items have more of these effects and reduced resists (than current). This lets Riot give the class the durability it's players have been crying for without everyone else abusing these unreducable effects.

I chose the other examples for similar reasons.
 - Mages: During the class update, Riot stated they wanted the class' itemization to focus on raw mana and tons of AP, while leaving regen to supports. Hence, they get the single biggest mana and AP boosts.
 - Marksman: Same as above. During their update, these are what Riot said should be the defining characteristics of ADC itemization. Crit for damage and MS/kiting for survival. Which is basically all the crit items these days. (>_>)
 - Fighter: While the class update was canceled, Fighters tend to get spread pretty thin in terms of stats. They need every stat under the sun and don't have the luxury of specializing (unlike everyone else). So the idea here here is to simplify their options. Health works against AD and AP roughly equally, so shooting that through the roof *at the expense of* other durability gives them a bit more flexibility. In a similar vane, letting them have health scaling bonuses (Titanic Hydra damage and Sterak's shield) lets them further specialize. Unfortunately, you can't really put a lot of MS in this class because of juggernauts, so they would have to rely items like Dead man's plate and maybe a specialized proto-belt. It's also important to remember that Rumble and Vlad exist, so health-scaling AP (or vice-versa) items could also be looked at.
 - Tank: See above.
 - Assassin: Itemization here is all about the windowed effects. Dusk blade, Luden, and mantle all have very potent non-stat steroids. Focusing more on these play's into assassins' "windowed" play patterns, where they will blow everyone out of the water all at once, then be a sitting duck for a while.
 - Support: The biggest problem with support itemization, historically, is the mandatory cost efficiency to be viable with their income stream. So other classes (especially when games get shorter) will poach their items to build an early lead while still getting core items later on (See pre-nerf FQC on mages and current Targon on ADC's). Riot tries to adjust this be adding powerful effects and Dumpstering the stats, but then we get actives that synergize too well with other class items and they get poach mid-late game (see Knight's, Locket, adn redemption on tanks). Or they just become too awkward to be viable (see Ohmwrecker). Isolating support itemization means that anyone going into this class is forced *out* of the core itemization provided other classess, making this a much bigger trade-off.
 
> As such I would either want these 'counter items' to be available to everyone or want certain classes of champions to have access to items from multiple categories, for example fighters or juggernauts should be given access to at least some of the tank items as well.

I'm fine with some items being cross-grouping if they only need to be restricted *from* a specific group.

> Yeah, I imagine that it would work best if the system were based off of a player choice of some kind. Players who pick a champion could have their pick between the various classes to gain access to those class specific items, and then in-game champions who are hybrid or who switch would either be given access to a second class's items or they would be given a choice to switch (like in Kayne's case) if they are forced to change or if they want to change.

Every champion should have access to every class. I see this as a pre-game choice just like runes. Letting champions switch classes during the match would likely cause all kinds of back-end problems; more so if we tie the  passive bonuses to it. Admittedly that does make Kayn the outlier in this system. But I'm not familiar enough with him to suggest solutions.

> Maybe people could even be given the freedom to build items outside of their chosen class, but until they select a different class, they don't get the full benefits of those items.

That could be interesting, but it is asking Riot to create multiple unique instances of all affected items. It would take the same amount of work to just create something entirely new targeted towards that class. 

> I personally think that by limiting choices by category or class, and by giving newer players recommendations, we could actually see the new player experience improved, and people would be less likely to do things like buy Rabadon's Deathcap or Randuin's Omen while playing something like Ashe.

Yes, in an Ashe it could be helpful, as long as they know she's a marksman and should take that class. Riot help her team if she decides to be durable and go tank. . .
They could put champion based restrictions for accounts under a specific level. It saves from the "worst case scenario" but also limits build exploration and could take a good chunk of time to implement. Tough call.
